page.title: 14Gt.Coxwell up to 1100 A.D.
page.content: The name Cocheswell,Cokkeswell, Cockyeswell,Coxwell is thought to come from Cokkes Wielle where Wielle is Old English for spring.Great Coxwell is situated on a spring line. Mesolithic flint flakes have been found north & west of the Great Barn. A Neolithic site has been found near the Iron Age Camp of Badbury Hill. There was evidence(Haematite ware) of an early Iron Age site by Foxley.Also a Roman-British site 200 yards from the Great Barn, & by the B4019 road. The sites were all discovered by field walking & dated by the identification of the artifacts & pottery sherds found. Coxwell is mentioned in the original Domesday Book & is said to have had a church.No remains were found of it during recent excavations of the present church floor.
